awd_titl_txt: Mid-Miocene Rhyolites of Eastern Oregon: Constraints for the Timing of Columbia River Basalt Volcanism and Associated Rhyolite Flare-up
awd_abstract_narration:
The Pacific Northwest of the United States is an area that has been affected by volcanic eruptions for millions of years. Volcanic activity is a direct consequence of processes that take place in the Earth's deep interior and, thus, studying volcanic rocks provides an important window into understanding fundamental aspects of the dynamic behavior of the earth. A particularly volcanic active period in the Pacific Northwest was from about 17 million to 14 million years ago. During this period, Oregon and Washington states were inundated by the basaltic lava flows of the Columbia River Basalt (CRB, in places hundreds of feet thick and covering in excess of 150,000 square miles. The cause of CRB volcanism has been debated for decades and researchers favor two alternative hypothesis. One is that melting is caused by a deep seated "mantle plume" originating hundreds of miles deep near the core/mantle boundary. The second interpretation is that melting takes place at shallower levels in the Earth's mantle, triggered in part by the active tectonics of the region. One important aspect in this discussion is how the thermal anomaly, as recorded by this voluminous volcanism, is behaving in time and space, in other words where did volcanism start and how did activity spread geographically with time. Just in the last few years, it has become apparent that CRB volcanism did not only produce basaltic lava flows but also rhyolite magmas. This research addresses primarily the timing of the newly recognized component of CRB volcanism based on radiometric age determinations. It is designed to provide a better understanding of where CRB volcanism started and how it spread. Volcanic vents for rhyolite magmas point more directly to a basalt magma at depth while fissure eruptions that fed basalt lava flows can happen long distances away from where basalt magmas from the Earth's mantle rose to the surface. 

The primary focus of this field and laboratory study is to fully document CRB related rhyolite volcanism of eastern Oregon in terms of distribution, composition, and timing focusing on a series of understudied mid-Miocene rhyolite centers. This will test the validity of current notions of a northward migration of co-CRB rhyolite volcanism starting at the McDermitt volcanic field and adjacent areas along the Oregon-Nevada border. This in turn will have implications for the significance of observed age progression in floodbasalts of the CRBG. McDermitt rhyolites have traditionally been viewed as the oldest rhyolites related to the CRB province, predating those that erupted further north in Oregon. Fieldwork, augmented by geochemical and petrographic data, will establish stratigraphic sequences at selected centers. After a conceptual framework of the evolution of a center has been established, a subset of samples will be selected for age analyses by 40Ar/39Ar single-crystal laser-fusion and incremental heating methods. Emphasis will be placed on dating stratigraphic sections where rhyolites are intercalated with CRB lavas in order to precisely constrain timing of CRB volcanism with attention to constraining the controversial age of the Grande Ronde Basalt.

por.por_cntn:
The Pacific Northwest of the United States is an area that was affected by volcanic eruptions and their deposits for millions of years. Volcanic activity is a direct consequence of processes that take place in the earth’s shallower and deeper interior and thus studying volcanic rocks provides an important window into understanding fundamental aspects of the dynamic behavior of the earth. A particularly volcanic active period in the Pacific NW was from about 17 million years to 14 million years ago. During this period, Oregon and Washington state were inundated by basaltic lava flows of the Columbia River Basalt (CRB) in places hundreds of feet thick and covering in excess of 150,000 square miles. The cause of CRB volcanism has been debated for decades. One important aspect in this discussion is how the thermal anomaly, as recorded by this voluminous volcanism, is behaving in time and space, in other words where did volcanism start and how did activity spread with time. Just in the last few years, it has become apparent that CRB volcanism did not only produce basaltic lava flows but also rhyolite magmas. This research primarily addressed the timing of the newly recognized rhyolites of the CRB magmatic province. Many rhyolite centers were known to exist in eastern Oregon but most of them were not associated with the CRB magmatic province because older radiometric dating indicated that these rhyolite centers are too young to be a direct response of the thermal pulse during CRB basalt intrusions into the crust.

We used radiometric techniques to date nearly all of the rhyolites that were known before but also some that we documented newly. We undertook field work prior selecting a subset of samples for dating and for obtaining other analytical data on composition and mineralogy of these rhyolites. Field work was done to document eruptive units of a rhyolite center and to use field relationships to put units into a relative age sequence as absolute ages by radiometric techniques can only be obtained on a subset of samples, hence such relative age constraints complement absolute ages. Field samples were taking from all main rhyolite centers for chemical and mineralogical analysis. With these field, analytical, and age data, we fully documented CRB related rhyolite volcanism of eastern Oregon in terms of distribution, composition, and timing and thus provided a better understanding of where CRB volcanism started and how it spread as rhyolite magmas point more clearly to a basalt magma at depth while fissure eruptions that fed basalt lava flows can happen large distances away from where basalt magmas from the earth’s mantle rose to the surface.

Our new data contradict the current held view that co-CRB rhyolite volcanism started at the McDermitt volcanic field and adjacent areas along the Oregon-Nevada border and migrated northward from there, which was based on the old and imprecise age data. McDermitt rhyolites have traditionally been viewed as the oldest rhyolites related to the CRB province, predating those that erupted further north. in our study area. We obtained radiometric ages as old as those of McDermitt and samples yielding such old ages are distributed across the entire footprint of mid Miocene rhyolites suggesting rhyolite volcanism was widespread from the onset but did not migrate northward. We determined that rhyolite eruptions gradually initiated at ~17.5 million years ago, and our new ages indicate peak intensity of a first eruptive episode occurred between 16.3 and 14.4 million years and this was directly associated with basaltic magmatism of the CRB. Younger rhyolite volcanism followed after a pause in rhyolite activity previously determined between ~15–12 that we refined to 14.4–12.1 milion years ago. After that, rhyolite eruptions strongly recommenced at 12.05 million years ago. Further analysis of our and published data, we find two prominent fluxes in rhyolite eruptive activity after 12.1 million years as opposed to one continuous age-progressive trend migrating from the co-CRB rhyolites across Oregon in a northwesterly direction that has been known as the High Lava Plains trend; one pulse was at 12.1–9.6 and the other one at 7.7–5.1 million years, separated by an ~2 millon year period of decreased rhyolite volcanism. We mainly attribute periodicity of rhyolite volcanism to punctuated basalt inputs from mantle such as the one that generated the CRB but becoming less voluminous with time.

Nine Masters students and one PhD student were impacted by this project as well as several undergraduate students. Of these 10 graduate students, 6 were female and one student was a veteran. A number of rhyolite complexes such as the Strawberry Mountain and Leslie Gulch area around Mahogany Mountains are popular travel destination among backcountry enthusiasts. All information on the volcanic rocks that crop out there are freely available and should also be useful for the non-expert as we
